Recommended Proteins.name: MAPT
Recommended Proteins.annotation: Microtubule-associated protein tau; Promotes microtubule assembly and stability, and might be involved in the establishment and maintenance of neuronal polarity. The C-terminus binds axonal microtubules while the N-terminus binds neural plasma membrane components, suggesting that tau functions as a linker protein between both. Axonal polarity is predetermined by TAU/MAPT localization (in the neuronal cell) in the domain of the cell body defined by the centrosome. The short isoforms allow plasticity of the cytoskeleton whereas the longer isoforms may preferentially play a role in its st [...]

Recommended Proteins.name: TTBK1
Recommended Proteins.annotation: Tau-tubulin kinase 1; Serine/threonine kinase which is able to phosphorylate TAU on serine, threonine and tyrosine residues. Induces aggregation of TAU.

Recommended Proteins.name: MARK3
Recommended Proteins.annotation: MAP/microtubule affinity-regulating kinase 3; Serine/threonine-protein kinase. Involved in the specific phosphorylation of microtubule-associated proteins for MAP2 and MAP4. Phosphorylates the microtubule-associated protein MAPT/TAU. Phosphorylates CDC25C on 'Ser-216'. Regulates localization and activity of some histone deacetylases by mediating phosphorylation of HDAC7, promoting subsequent interaction between HDAC7 and 14-3-3 and export from the nucleus. Negatively regulates the Hippo signaling pathway and antagonizes the phosphorylation of LATS1. Cooperates with DLG5 to inhibit the  [...]

Recommended Proteins.name: MARK4
Recommended Proteins.annotation: MAP/microtubule affinity-regulating kinase 4; Serine/threonine-protein kinase. Phosphorylates the microtubule-associated protein MAPT/TAU. Also phosphorylates the microtubule-associated proteins MAP2 and MAP4. Involved in regulation of the microtubule network, causing reorganization of microtubules into bundles. Required for the initiation of axoneme extension during cilium assembly. Regulates the centrosomal location of ODF2 and phosphorylates ODF2 in vitro. Plays a role in cell cycle progression, specifically in the G1/S checkpoint. Reduces neuronal cell survival. Plays a role in ene [...]

Recommended Proteins.name: MARK1
Recommended Proteins.annotation: Serine/threonine-protein kinase MARK1; Serine/threonine-protein kinase. Involved in cell polarity and microtubule dynamics regulation. Phosphorylates DCX, MAP2 and MAP4. Phosphorylates the microtubule-associated protein MAPT/TAU. Involved in cell polarity by phosphorylating the microtubule-associated proteins MAP2, MAP4 and MAPT/TAU at KXGS motifs, causing detachment from microtubules, and their disassembly. Involved in the regulation of neuronal migration through its dual activities in regulating cellular polarity and microtubule dynamics, possibly by phosphorylating and regulating DC [...]

Recommended Proteins.name: MAP4
Recommended Proteins.annotation: Microtubule-associated protein 4; Non-neuronal microtubule-associated protein. Promotes microtubule assembly.

Recommended Proteins.name: TTBK2
Recommended Proteins.annotation: Tau-tubulin kinase 2; Serine/threonine kinase that acts as a key regulator of ciliogenesis: controls the initiation of ciliogenesis by binding to the distal end of the basal body and promoting the removal of CCP110, which caps the mother centriole, leading to the recruitment of IFT proteins, which build the ciliary axoneme. Has some substrate preference for proteins that are already phosphorylated on a Tyr residue at the +2 position relative to the phosphorylation site. Able to phosphorylate tau on serines in vitro.

Recommended Proteins.name: MARK2
Recommended Proteins.annotation: Serine/threonine-protein kinase MARK2; Serine/threonine-protein kinase. Involved in cell polarity and microtubule dynamics regulation. Phosphorylates CRTC2/TORC2, DCX, HDAC7, KIF13B, MAP2, MAP4 and RAB11FIP2. Phosphorylates the microtubule-associated protein MAPT/TAU. Plays a key role in cell polarity by phosphorylating the microtubule-associated proteins MAP2, MAP4 and MAPT/TAU at KXGS motifs, causing detachment from microtubules, and their disassembly. Regulates epithelial cell polarity by phosphorylating RAB11FIP2. Involved in the regulation of neuronal migration through its dual ac [...]

Recommended Proteins.name: MAP2
Recommended Proteins.annotation: Microtubule-associated protein 2; The exact function of MAP2 is unknown but MAPs may stabilize the microtubules against depolymerization. They also seem to have a stiffening effect on microtubules.

properties.annotation: Microtubule-associated protein tau; Promotes microtubule assembly and stability, and might be involved in the establishment and maintenance of neuronal polarity. The C-terminus binds axonal microtubules while the N-terminus binds neural plasma membrane components, suggesting that tau functions as a linker protein between both. Axonal polarity is predetermined by TAU/MAPT localization (in the neuronal cell) in the domain of the cell body defined by the centrosome. The short isoforms allow plasticity of the cytoskeleton whereas the longer isoforms may preferentially play a role in its st [...]

Relationships.explanation: The interaction is relevant because TTBK1 directly phosphorylates MAPT (tau), impacting tau's function. This phosphorylation can induce tau aggregation, crucial for understanding tau-related neurodegenerative processes.

properties.annotation: Tau-tubulin kinase 2; Serine/threonine kinase that acts as a key regulator of ciliogenesis: controls the initiation of ciliogenesis by binding to the distal end of the basal body and promoting the removal of CCP110, which caps the mother centriole, leading to the recruitment of IFT proteins, which build the ciliary axoneme. Path Details.details:
MAPT -> TTBK1:
The interaction is relevant. TTBK1 directly phosphorylates MAPT. MAPT promotes microtubule stability, while TTBK1 phosphorylates and induces aggregation of MAPT, potentially affecting neuronal polarity and cytoskeletal plasticity.

TTBK1 -> TTBK2:
The interaction is relevant because TTBK1 and TTBK2 both phosphorylate tau (MAPT). TTBK1 can phosphorylate TAU on multiple residues, and TTBK2 can phosphorylate tau on serines, aligning with the query's goal.

properties.annotation: Serine/threonine-protein kinase MARK2; Serine/threonine-protein kinase. Involved in cell polarity and microtubule dynamics regulation. Phosphorylates CRTC2/TORC2, DCX, HDAC7, KIF13B, MAP2, MAP4 and RAB11FIP2. Phosphorylates the microtubule-associated protein MAPT/TAU. Plays a key role in cell polarity by phosphorylating the microtubule-associated proteins MAP2, MAP4 and MAPT/TAU at KXGS motifs, causing detachment from microtubules, and their disassembly. Path Details.explanation: The path MAP4 -> MARK4 -> MARK3 is relevant because MARK4 directly phosphorylates MAPT, fulfilling the query requirement. Path Details.details:
MAPT -> MAP4:
The interaction between MAPT and MAP4 is not relevant to the query because there is no evidence that MAP4 directly phosphorylates MAPT. Both proteins promote microtubule assembly but do not interact in this manner.

MAP4 -> MARK4:
The interaction is relevant because MARK4 directly phosphorylates MAPT, as stated in the end_annotation. MAP4 is phosphorylated by MARK4, indicating a direct regulatory relationship between MAP4 and MARK4, fulfilling the query's requirement.

MARK4 -> MARK3:
The interaction between MARK4 and MARK3 is relevant as both phosphorylate MAPT/TAU. MARK4's role includes reorganization of the microtubule network, while MARK3 regulates microtubule-associated protein phosphorylation, impacting MAPT/TAU directly.

properties.annotation: Microtubule-associated protein tau; Promotes microtubule assembly and stability, and might be involved in the establishment and maintenance of neuronal polarity. The C-terminus binds axonal microtubules while the N-terminus binds neural plasma membrane components, suggesting that tau functions as a linker protein between both. Axonal polarity is predetermined by TAU/MAPT localization (in the neuronal cell) in the domain of the cell body defined by the centrosome. Path Details.details:
MAPT -> MAP4:
The interaction is not relevant. MAPT (Tau) and MAP4 are both microtubule-associated proteins promoting microtubule assembly, but there is no evidence or mechanism indicating that MAP4 phosphorylates MAPT directly.

MAP4 -> MARK4:
The interaction is relevant as MARK4 directly phosphorylates MAPT and also phosphorylates MAP4. MAP4 promotes microtubule assembly, which is relevant to the cellular processes involving MAPT phosphorylation by MARK4.

MARK4 -> MAP2:
The interaction between MARK4 and MAP2 is relevant. MARK4 directly phosphorylates MAP2, and MAP2 stabilizes microtubules. This fits the query as the end protein, MAP2, directly interacts with MAPT/TAU through phosphorylation.
